awd_titl_txt: Dissection of subcellular sites of NLR function during immune signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
Resistance proteins (R-proteins) are key players in a plant's defensive repertoire against pathogenic microbes. R-proteins act as sentinels that recognize incursion by a pathogen and initiate responses to limit the extent of infection. Although we understand in some detail the nature of the initial recognition event, little is known about how R-proteins signal to the plant that defenses need to be deployed. This project follows the intriguing observation that at least some R-proteins, once activated by a pathogen, interact with other proteins to stimulate enhanced expression of genes required to mount an effective immune response. The research to be carried out seeks to enhance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that mediate these events. The results are likely to contribute new strategies for developing crop varieties that are resistant to economically significant plant diseases. The project will provide training for a postdoctoral researcher and a graduate student. Undergraduate students from under-represented minorities and economically disadvantaged students from the Biology Undergraduate Scholars Program (BUSP) will be trained. The project will also teach and train a high school student from Young Scholar Program (YSP) at UC Davis. The project will organize a science field trip for 5th grade students from an Elementary School to UC Davis.


In plants and animals, the Nucleotide-binding domain and Leucine-rich Repeat (NLR) class of intracellular immune receptors function in defense against pathogens. Despite extensive research, post-pathogen recognition events leading to NLR activation and induction of defense signaling remain elusive. The investigators recent results indicate that the plant NLR N associates with the SPL6 protein in the nucleus to activate successful immune response against Tobacco Mosaic Virus (TMV). SPL6 is also required for NLR RPS4-mediated defense against Pseudomonas syringae bacteria expressing AvrRps4 effector. Therefore, SPL6 appears to be a conserved nuclear component that acts as a bridge between an activated NLR and induction of defense genes. In this project, the investigators will use a combination of genetic, molecular, biochemical, genomics, proteomics, and cell biology based approaches to understand the subcellular dynamics of NLRs during immune signaling. Precise function of SPL6 during immune signaling will be determined by identification and characterization of direct target genes that are regulated by SPL6. Also SPL6 interacting proteins will be identified and characterized. Results from the project will advance the field of immunity by providing mechanistic insights into NLRs function especially with respect to their spatial distribution and dynamics during defense. Knowledge gained will improve our understanding of plant immunity, help harness it to aid in the development of pathogen resistant crops and promote food security.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The innate immune system of both plants and animals employs cell-surface and intracellular receptors to detect pathogens and trigger defenses. In this project using N TIR-NLR immune receptor as a model system, we showed that activation of defense requires immune receptor dimerization step followed by association with SPL6 transcription factor in the nucleus. We optimized proximity labeling (PL) approach in plants and identified novel new players in NLR-mediated defense. Specifically, we identified helper NLRs, a receptor-like kinase, transcriptional co-activator, aspartyl protease and others as a regulator of NLR-mediated defense. Interestingly, a novel E3 ubiquitin ligase, UBR7 plays an important role in the regulation of N protein level. UBR7 E3 ligase interacts with N TIR-NLR in the absence of infection to keep N protein level low. Upon infection, TMV-p50 effector interferes with N-UBR7 interaction and hence N is stabilized and activates immune response. Using bioinformatics and follow up functional analysis, we have identified the role for TIR adaptors function in NLR-mediated immunity. Using ChIP-Seq approach, we identified direct targets of SPL6 transcription factor during immunity. In addition, we have identified interactors of SPL6 and an immune modulator EDS1 protein. We determined that unlike other NLRs, Sw-5b NLR recognizes a PAMP-like effector region in tospoviruses and also demonstrated that Sw-5b uses a two-step recognition mechanism involving N-terminal and LRR domains to activate robust defense against tospoviruses. We found that SPL1 and SPL12 transcription factors play a role in basal immune response. Combining crystal structure data of BIK1 receptor-like kinase and EFR immune receptor-mediated phosphorylation sites on BIK1, we showed hitherto unknown role for jasmonic acid in bacterial immunity. In addition, we showed the role for BIK1 in the nucleus during basal defense. BIK1 is stabilized by SIK1 MAP4K and regulates reactive oxygen species burst during immunity. We showed that a receptor-like kinase PBL13 phosphorylates C-terminus of RbohD and regulates its stability and activity. We identified an E3 ubiquitin ligase that interacts with PBL13 and RbohD to regulate basal immunity. We developed a split superfolder green fluorescent protein (sfGFP)-based approach to monitor the spatiotemporal dynamics of effectors delivered directly from bacterial pathogens into plant cells. Finally, we showed that pathogen effectors target AuTophaGy (ATG) proteins to dampen immunity.

 

Broader Impacts: We provided training to research scientist, post-docs, graduate students, undergraduate students, visiting students, visiting scientists and high school students under this project. We have distributed the materials generated under this grant to the scientific community through Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC), Ohio and through Addgene. We have published our findings in scientific publications and also presented our findings in national and international meetings and symposiums. We have conducted two hands on scientific modules to K-6th grade students (about 100 students) as part of science night at Davis Pioneer Elementary School -- "See your DNA" module and "Importance of washing hands and Germs" module.
